--- In rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com, Miles Sabin <miles@m...> wrote:
> inthedarkplace wrote,
> > Often time, the user uses POST to create a new resource. This
> > resource creation often requires authentication. HTTP authentication,
> > which is challenge-response, conflicts with this; if the user POSTs a
> > relatively large resource entity and the server challenges, the
> > entity is lost. What to do in this scenario? How are others solving
> > this problem?
> 
> Lost? Only if the client discards it before reposting with 
> authentication.
> 
> If it's a problem keeping a large POST entity around during the 
> challenge-response you could investigate 100 Continue (see RFC 2616 
> 8.2.3). The client can add an Accept: 100-continue request header and 
> pause before generating and sending the request entity. If the POST is 
> authenticated (or no auth is required) the server will respond with a 
> 100 Continue response and the client can proceed with the request 
> entity. OTOH if auth is required the server will respond with a 401 
> Unauthorized and client can terminate the request without ever 
> generating or sending the request entity.
> 
> I believe that server support for 100 Continue is fairly good. 
> Unfortunately client support is pretty patchy (I'm pretty sure it's not 
> supported by the standard Java HTTP client) but clients with support do 
> exist. Not sure what the situation is with proxies tho'.

I had hope--100 Continue seemed like an elegant solution--but I don't
think it can be used here. Really, the only valid responses of
'Expect: 100-continue' is '417 Expectation Failed' and '100 Continue'.
It can't be used for preauthentication.

- itdp
